image.altText: Melanie Morris and her nine year-old daughter, Kaitlyn Morris 1

items.synopsis: Melanie Morris vividly remembers the sense of searing anger as she held her sick toddler in her arms in the emergency department of Launceston's general hospital for the fourth time in a week, back in 2015. Years on, the question is — are things getting any better?

title.children: 'I'm a doctor, you're only a mother': Melanie had to fight to get her barely responsive child an X-ray for an obstruction

image.altText: youth crime vandalism Bridgewater affordable housing

items.synopsis: In Tasmania, social housing is in short supply and efforts are being made to build new homes as quickly as possible. But as soon as construction starts, it is targeted by teenage vandals.

title.children: Vandals do $25k damage in one hour at affordable houses project

image.altText: A woman sits in a room atop a suitcase and surrounded by other paperwork and memories

items.synopsis: Beth Heinrich has become the public face of a battle to see the Anglican church admit its failings in its handling of historical child sexual abuse claims, holding onto a battered, brown suitcase of "love letters", photographs and trinkets.

title.children: ‘My Darling, thank you for coming into my life’: Why Beth still holds onto letters from her abuser

image.altText: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese in Perth

items.synopsis: Financial support for single parents will continue until their youngest dependent child turns 14, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese announces.

title.children: Single parenting payment cut-off lifted from eight to 14

image.altText: A close up shot of a woman's face from the side. She's wearing over-ear headphones.

items.synopsis: We’re entering a new era of artificial intelligence, where human-like conversation and images can be created with the click of a button. Already, the powerful technology is changing our lives — for better or worse.

title.children: Alanah has lost track of the amount of porn of her being shared. It's all fake

image.altText: Snow in Bungendore NSW

items.synopsis: A cold front brings icy weather, snow and hail to large swathes of the country with some places clocking record cold temperatures for May. The BOM is warning the cold snap isn't over yet.

title.children: Cold front delivers snow, hail to large parts of Australia with more cold weather to come

image.altText: Two men in suits shake hands as they meet ouside under a grey sky.

items.synopsis: Beijing accuses Australia of trying to sabotage its relationship with Fiji as questions swirl over whether the Pacific Island country will cut security ties with Beijing.

title.children: Australia accused of undermining Fiji-China relationship, amid uncertainty over police agreement

image.altText: Man wearing grey suit and glasses.

items.synopsis: The man who led the prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann over the alleged rape of Brittany Higgins tells an inquiry he "should have paid closer attention" during a meeting with Lisa Wilkinson ahead of her Logies speech, which prompted a delay to the trial.

title.children: 'I'm not a publicist': ACT's top prosecutor responds to criticism over advice to Lisa Wilkinson ahead of Logies

image.altText: a man in handcuffs taken by police away from court into a police wagon

items.synopsis: The victim says she had the "world at her feet" before the night of the assault and has found social media comments about her case "extremely difficult".

title.children: Woman sexually assaulted by Jarryd Hayne speaks out about 'never-ending nightmare'

image.altText: A police officer stands in uniform, in a room with the Australian flag behind him

items.synopsis: Police and human rights advocates warn against vigilante behaviour after a group of residents marched on the homes of alleged offenders following an anti-crime rally in Rockhampton, on one occasion chasing a person down the street.

title.children: Police call for calm after angry locals rally against crime in Central Queensland

image.altText: A Jehovah's Witness Bible.

items.synopsis: A Jehovah's Witness woman who bled to death in a Newcastle hospital may have survived if she revoked her wishes to refuse a transfusion on religious grounds, an inquest hears.

title.children: Inquest told only a court could overturn blood transfusion refusal by Jehovah's Witness

image.altText: Composite image of Rebecca White and proposed Hobart stadium.

items.synopsis: With the Tasmanian Liberals still on a victory lap over the Hobart AFL stadium deal with the Federal Labor government, the state Labor leader at some point will need to be clear about what her game plan is, writes Adam Langenberg.

title.children: Will Labor kill the stadium? Their game plan is not yet clear

image.altText: A smiling woman with blond hair wearing a dark jacket and green top stands outside.

items.synopsis: The $14.6 billion package over the forward estimates includes $1.5 billion in electricity bill relief for more than 5 million households and a further 1 million small businesses.

title.children: Electricity bill relief receives mixed reviews as federal government reveals $14.6b cost of living package

image.altText: Bolivian general Gary Prado Salmon. He is shown as a man in his 60s with a grey mustache, short white hair, wearing white shirt.

items.synopsis: General Gary Prado Salmón was feted as a national hero for leading the military operation that led to Guevara's capture in 1967.

title.children: Bolivian general who captured Che Guevara dies

image.altText: Shane Patton is in his navy blue full police chief uniform as he sits looking seriously at a table adorned with native leaves.

items.synopsis: Victoria's police chief Shane Patton apologises for actions that have traumatised Indigenous people at the state's truth-telling inquiry. WARNING: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised that this article contains images and names of people who have died.

title.children: 'I wish to formally and unreservedly apologise': Police chief's apology for treatment of Indigenous Victorians

items.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says that Labor inherited a trillion dollars of "Liberal debt" when it came to office, and that Labor's share of that, left to the previous Coalition government was "a tiny fraction". RMIT ABC Fact Check runs the numbers.

title.children: We fact checked Jim Chalmers on the amount of debt Labor left the Coalition. Here's what we found

image.altText: APRA Grenfell St 2

items.synopsis: The federal government spends about $650 billion a year. Where some of it goes will surprise you.

title.children: Morrison government gave $380,000 to social media company that also makes explicit content

image.altText: A profile image of Md Isfaqur Rahman wearing a white shirt, tie and jacket.

items.synopsis: Brendan Kantilla is charged with the murder of international student Md Isfaqur Rahman, who died after he was allegedly assaulted during a home invasion in Darwin's northern suburbs last week.

title.children: Man fronts court charged with murder of Bangladeshi student in Darwin following alleged home invasion

image.altText: A drum with contents inside buried in dirt.

items.synopsis: A New South Wales man accused of hiding $1.5 million worth of cocaine in an underground barrel on the Darwin Esplanade has been denied bail after arguing it should be granted because he is the "main breadwinner" for his young family.

title.children: Man accused of burying $1.5m worth of cocaine near Darwin CBD denied bail

image.altText: A man  bows his head solemnly as he stands with other relatives of gold miners who are trapped in a Peruvian gold mine

items.synopsis: Government officials are investigating the cause of a fire deep in a gold mine in southern Peru which has killed at least 27 workers.

title.children: Fire in gold mine kills at least 27 workers in southern Peru

image.altText: A Russian guard in military uniform, holding a rifle, while standing in front of a large industrial building.

items.synopsis: Russian soldiers order civilians to leave towns surrounding the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, amid renewed warnings that nearby fighting could cause "a severe nuclear accident".

title.children: Civilians ordered to leave amid fears for Ukrainian nuclear plant

image.altText: A composite image of Vladimir Putin, Xi Jinping and Joe Biden

items.synopsis: Washington will never be able to deliver Vladimir Putin to the negotiating table. The Chinese president knew this when on a sunny spring morning in Ukraine's capital, Xi Jinping deigned to finally speak to Volodymyr Zelenskyy, writes John Lyons in Kyiv.

title.children: China has swooped — and it's leaving the US in its dust in Ukraine

image.altText: A woman in a hospital bed is about to be kissed by her tan dachshund.

items.synopsis: The Olympian was preparing to take part in a show jumping competition when she collapsed from a ruptured aorta, and was attended to by a doctor and vet at the show, saving her life.

title.children: Three-time Olympian Vicki Roycroft back home after near-death experience

image.altText: Jock takes a selfie with the other judges.

items.synopsis: Tributes flow for celebrated chef Jock Zonfrillo ahead of the debut episode of the new season of MasterChef Australia.

title.children: 'Hard as nails but vulnerable': Tributes flow for celebrated chef Jock Zonfrillo as MasterChef returns to air

image.altText: Tom and Shiv look at each other seriously during a party.

items.synopsis: It's the night before the election, and the entire conservative media elite have gathered in Tom and Shiv's apartment. But gate crashers threaten to foil Kendall and Roman's plans.

title.children: Succession recap: Please check on the Tom Wambsgans stans in your life

image.altText: Jim Chalmers speaks at a press conference

items.synopsis: Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers says he has let most of the money from higher commodity prices and low unemployment "flow through" to the bottom line ahead of unveiling tomorrow's budget.

title.children: Treasurer says he has banked a tax boon to close budget's deficit gap

image.altText: Person holds up sign in protest against the King amongst a crowd of people in London

items.synopsis: The UK's Republic Group is considering suing the police after 64 protesters were arrested on King Charles III's Coronation Day.

title.children: Anti-monarchists criticise police over Coronation Day arrests

image.altText: People speaking outside court with one holding a placard reading 'truth will win in the end'

items.synopsis: Sovereign citizens don't believe the laws apply to them, so they challenge any punitive measures in court. A NSW magistrate warns this is having serious consequences for everyone.

title.children: A 300-page response to a parking fine: Why sovereign citizens are straining the local court systems

image.altText: King Charles looks out of the rain-spattered window of a carriage

items.synopsis: The coronation is done and dusted, but the spectacle has reignited debates about slavery, colonial legacies and republicanism.

title.children: Why King Charles's coronation may accelerate the shrinking of the Commonwealth

image.altText: Kate Middleton waves UK flag during coronation concert

items.synopsis: The coronation concert for King Charles saw performances from Lionel Richie and Katy Perry, but it's how the royals celebrated the night that captured viewers. Here are the key moments.

title.children: A dancing duchess, a heartfelt message to 'Pa', but a lack of Louis: The best bits from King Charles's coronation concert

image.altText: A red, abstracted "W" logo fixed to a white background.

items.synopsis: The Australian share market continues to trade higher as Westpac posts a $4 billion profit in its half-yearly results. Follow the day's events as they happen with our live blog.

title.children: Westpac shares jump as bank records $4 billion profit in half-yearly results, ASX continues to gain

schema.headline: Live updates: ASX keeps gaining, Westpac shares jump as bank records $4 billion profit in half-yearly results

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Big four banks earn combined $16.77 billion in half-yearly results
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Analysis from EY shows Australia's big four banks reported combined statutory earnings of $16.77 billion in their half-yearly results — a 10.8% increase compared to this time last year. But EY says the major banks are walking a "challenging tightrope" and will have to manage competing demands from investors, customers, regulators and government in "an increasingly uncertain and volatile backdrop". EY says cash rate rises are boosting revenues and net interest margins, while higher earnings have pushed up return on equity, although some signs of mortgage stress are emerging. "Australia's major banks are walking a tightrope as headwinds for the sector intensify. The resilience of the Australian economy continued to support credit growth and quality throughout the first half of the year," said EY Oceania Banking and Capital Markets Leader, Doug Nixon. "However, intense competition in response to retail credit growth compression, coupled with rising funding costs, amplified by the recent dislocation in financial markets, will likely erode the benefits the banks have gained from the higher interest rate environment. "So, while Australia's major banks remain strong and resilient, pressure on net interest margins, combined with the increasingly uncertain operating environment, means they face a complex high-wire balancing act when it comes to managing profitable growth, customer expectations, investment priorities and shareholder returns."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Binance resumes bitcoin withdrawals after 'large volume' of transactions
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The world's largest crypto-currency exchange, Binance, has resumed bitcoin withdrawals after it was stopped twice today due to a large volume of pending transactions. The company tweeted that it had temporarily closed withdrawals because there were too many transactions, and its team was working on a fix. It isn't the first time Binance has suspended transactions, either. Back in March, it stopped deposits and withdrawals because of what it described as "technical issues". The price of bitcoin is down to its lowest in nearly a week, at around $41,000. Withdrawals have since resumed.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: $14.6 billion cost of living relief package won't make inflation worse, treasurer says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Speaking on RN Breakfast earlier, Treasurer Jim Chalmers told host Patricia Karvelas that the impending cost of living relief package won't add to inflation. The $14.6 billion package will include energy bill relief, as well as changes to JobSeeker and Commonwealth rental assistance. You can listen back to his full chat below:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ASX moving higher at lunch as materials and energy stocks rally
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The ASX is continuing to gain throughout trade today, up 0.7% as of 1pm AEST to 7,266 points. The gains are largely thanks to boosts in the energy and materials sectors, while Westpac is continuing to pick up after its half-yearly results, up 2.3%. Here's how the top five movers are currently looking: Lynas Rare Earths +10.8% Core Lithium +7.3% Life360 +7.1% Iluka Resources +5.3% Pilbara Minerals +4.8% Meanwhile at the other end, the five worst performers are a mixed bag: Block -5.4% Syrah Resources -4.7% Macquarie Group -2.4% Polynovo -1.9% Bellevue Gold -1.8%

liveBlogUpdate.headline: PRRT changes could have collected 'a lot more revenue', former ACCC chair says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: We can expect to hear a lot about changes to the Petroleum Resources Rent Tax (PRRT for short) in tomorrow's federal budget — with the government flagging changes to collect $2.4 billion over four years. The Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association (APPEA) has also endorsed the changes to the tax, but says it must be the last. It's not exactly a small amount of money, but former chair of the ACCC Rod Sims says he would have gone further, boosting the budget's bottom line even more. You can listen to his full chat with RN Breakfast's Patricia Karvelas below:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Business conditions are easing but are still at above-average levels
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: That's according to NAB's monthly business survey, which says business conditions eased in April but are still higher than average, due to enduring demand and a strong labour market. But it's not the same story for business confidence — it remains below average, despite a minor rise last month. NAB chief economist Alan Oster says business conditions remain strong, particularly in transport, utilities and mining, while construction remains the softest. "[This] reflects the ongoing challenge of elevated input prices putting pressure on profits for businesses in the building sector," he said. "[Business] confidence is still below average but has stabilised around 0 index points over recent months. "A zero reading for confidence in the survey indicates that an equal share of firms are optimistic as pessimistic, which highlights how the outlook is finely balanced. "Overall, the survey shows the economy remains resilient."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Looking for comprehensive federal budget coverage?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Let my colleagues answer all of your burning questions about the budget and help you make sense of it all. They're putting together a special half-hour coverage of The Business dedicated to all things budget tomorrow night from 9:30pm AEST. From expert analysis from business leaders and economists to insights from our specialist reporters who have crunched the numbers, here's a little taste of what you can expect:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: 'Other people doing dumb things' will create investing opportunities: Warren Buffett
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Berkshire Hathaway Chairman and CEO Warren Buffett fielded a number of shareholder questions during an AGM, including about the future of the US economy. Buffett was asked about the future of investing in particular as AI becomes more prevalent, before he boiled down his value investing strategy to a simple sentence: "What gives you opportunities is other people doing dumb things." "In the 58 years we’ve been running Berkshire, I would say there’s been a great increase in the number people doing dumb things, and they do big dumb things," he said. In layman's terms — investors focused on value are presented with investment opportunities when other people make bad decisions. You can watch his full response to the question below:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ASX opens higher, led by resources gains
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: As expected, the Australian share market has opened higher for the week, up 0.9% at the start of trade. There are big gains across the resources sector, namely Lynas — the Malaysian-based company announced it can continue to operate until January 1, 2024 after a licence variation. Previously its licence was set to expire on July 1. That's been music to the ears of investors, with its share price up 11% so far. Other big movers so far include: Lake Resources +5% Karoon Energy +3.8% Core Lithium +3.1% Champion Iron +2.9% At the other end, Bellevue Gold has dropped the most so far — it's down 2%. The other major falls have gone to: De Grey Mining -1.6% Evolution Mining +1.3% Cochlear -1.1% Capricorn Metals -1% And unsurprisingly, Westpac has had some positive movement — so far its share price is up 3% thanks to its mammoth $4 billion profit posted in its half-yearly results.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Here's how the market's looking at 10:15am AEST
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: ASX 200 : +0.9% to 7,288 points All Ords: +0.9% to 7,484 points Australian dollar : flat at 67.51 US cents On Wall Street: Dow +1.7%, S & P 500 +1.9%, Nasdaq +2.25% In Europe: FTSE 100 +1.0%, Stoxx 50 +1.25% Spot gold: flat at $US2,016.43/ounce Brent crude: flat at $US75.30/barrel Iron ore: -0.7% to $US98.70 a tonne Bitcoin: -3.1% at $US28,597

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Watch: Finance minister tight-lipped on potential budget surplus
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: When asked by News Breakfast's Michael Rowland about whether the federal government will deliver a surplus, finance minister Katy Gallagher wasn't giving anything away, but said there's "significant improvements in the short-term".

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Budget to include $1.9 billion package to extend single parent payments
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is speaking in Perth and has mentioned another cost of living relief measure coming in tomorrow night's budget. He's announced the extension of the financial safety net for single parent families, by raising the cut-off age for the youngest child of a single parent from 8 to 14 years. That change will see a fortnightly increase by $176.90 a fortnight, and will cost the budget some $1.9 billion over the next four years, to 2026-27. The change reverses a decision that was made by the Gillard government.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Will the cost of living relief package be inflationary?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Finance minister Katy Gallagher says the government has "been mindful" that their decisions in the budget won't drive up inflation. She's told News Breakfast the measures have been "very carefully calibrated" and "carefully targeted". "We've been really mindful of that [inflation] as we've been putting the decisions in," she said. "It's affordable because we've been making savings on the other side of the  budget. We're trying to do a few  things, cost of living relief,  investing in the future production side of the economy, but also  repairing the budget at the same  time to deal with the debt and  deficit that we inherited. "Budgets are always hundreds if not thousands of decisions working together to  produce the final outcome. People  will judge that on Tuesday night. "But we've been very mindful of those cost of living pressures Australians as we've been finalising it."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What's in the $14.6 billion cost of living package in the budget?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Let's unpack what's going to be one of the centrepieces of the federal government's budget tomorrow night. One of the key measures that makes up this $14.6 billion relief package over four years includes a $1.5 billion energy bill subsidy for more than 5 million households and 1 million small businesses. Those eligible (pensioners, small businesses, and those on income support) will receive up to $500 relief on their power bills, but the size of the assistance depends on where you live. You can hear more about the energy bill relief package in tomorrow night's budget here:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Westpac records $4 billion net profit in half-year results
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Westpac is the latest major bank to post its half-yearly results, recording a $4 billion net profit — up 22% compared to this time last year. The bank is also increasing dividends to 70 cents per share, an increase of 15%. Westpac says the increase to its net profit was boosted by improving margins, thanks to rising interest rates and growth in home and business loans.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Here's the state of play as of 7:30am AEST
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: ASX SPI 200 futures: +0.9% to 7,284 Australian dollar: 67.47 US cents On Wall Street: Dow +1.7%, S & P 500 +1.9%, Nasdaq +2.25% In Europe: FTSE 100 +1.0%, Stoxx 50 +1.25% Spot gold: $US2,016.54 Iron ore: $US98.70/tonne Bitcoin : $US28,987.23

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ASX set to open higher on federal budget eve
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Good morning and welcome to another week — it's Monday, May 8 and budget eve. If you're as excited as I am about the budget (you are on a markets and financial blog, after all) you'll have keenly spotted the federal government is out spruiking a near- $15 billion cost of living package to be unveiled in tomorrow night's budget. The $14.6 billion support package over four years is aimed to ease pressure on households and businesses, including $1.5 billion for electricity bill relief for 5.5 million households and 1 million small businesses. (I'll unpack what we know about the relief package shortly.) On the markets front, we can expect the local sharemarket to open higher with ASX futures up, and greater investor sentiment thanks to all three major benchmarks gaining. Investors are also waiting for Westpac's half yearly results, which have just dropped as I post this. Let's get into it, shall we?

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: Live updates: ASX keeps gaining, Westpac shares jump as bank records $4 billion profit in half-yearly results

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ASX 200 : +0.7% to 7,266 points All Ords: +0.7% to 7,461 points Australian dollar : +0.2% at 67.63 US cents On Wall Street: Dow +1.7%, S & P 500 +1.9%, Nasdaq +2.25% In Europe: FTSE 100 +1.0%, Stoxx 50 +1.25% Spot gold: +0.2% at $US2,020.23/ounce Brent crude: +0.2% at $US75.46/barrel Iron ore: -0.7% to $US98.70 a tonne Bitcoin: -4.2% at $US28,297
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Here's how the market's faring as of 1pm AEST

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Analysis from EY shows Australia's big four banks reported combined statutory earnings of $16.77 billion in their half-yearly results — a 10.8% increase compared to this time last year. But EY says the major banks are walking a "challenging tightrope" and will have to manage competing demands from investors, customers, regulators and government in "an increasingly uncertain and volatile backdrop". EY says cash rate rises are boosting revenues and net interest margins, while higher earnings have pushed up return on equity, although some signs of mortgage stress are emerging. "Australia's major banks are walking a tightrope as headwinds for the sector intensify. The resilience of the Australian economy continued to support credit growth and quality throughout the first half of the year," said EY Oceania Banking and Capital Markets Leader, Doug Nixon. "However, intense competition in response to retail credit growth compression, coupled with rising funding costs, amplified by the recent dislocation in financial markets, will likely erode the benefits the banks have gained from the higher interest rate environment. "So, while Australia's major banks remain strong and resilient, pressure on net interest margins, combined with the increasingly uncertain operating environment, means they face a complex high-wire balancing act when it comes to managing profitable growth, customer expectations, investment priorities and shareholder returns."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The world's largest crypto-currency exchange, Binance, has resumed bitcoin withdrawals after it was stopped twice today due to a large volume of pending transactions. The company tweeted that it had temporarily closed withdrawals because there were too many transactions, and its team was working on a fix. It isn't the first time Binance has suspended transactions, either. Back in March, it stopped deposits and withdrawals because of what it described as "technical issues". The price of bitcoin is down to its lowest in nearly a week, at around $41,000. Withdrawals have since resumed.

"[This] reflects the ongoing challenge of elevated input prices putting pressure on profits for businesses in the building sector," he said.
"[Business] confidence is still below average but has stabilised around 0 index points over recent months.
"A zero reading for confidence in the survey indicates that an equal share of firms are optimistic as pessimistic, which highlights how the outlook is finely balanced.
"Overall, the survey shows the economy remains resilient."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Berkshire Hathaway Chairman and CEO Warren Buffett fielded a number of shareholder questions during an AGM, including about the future of the US economy. Buffett was asked about the future of investing in particular as AI becomes more prevalent, before he boiled down his value investing strategy to a simple sentence: "What gives you opportunities is other people doing dumb things." "In the 58 years we’ve been running Berkshire, I would say there’s been a great increase in the number people doing dumb things, and they do big dumb things," he said. In layman's terms — investors focused on value are presented with investment opportunities when other people make bad decisions. You can watch his full response to the question below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Other people doing dumb things' will create investing opportunities: Warren Buffett

"In the 58 years we’ve been running Berkshire, I would say there’s been a great increase in the number people doing dumb things, and they do big dumb things," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As expected, the Australian share market has opened higher for the week, up 0.9% at the start of trade. There are big gains across the resources sector, namely Lynas — the Malaysian-based company announced it can continue to operate until January 1, 2024 after a licence variation. Previously its licence was set to expire on July 1. That's been music to the ears of investors, with its share price up 11% so far. Other big movers so far include: Lake Resources +5% Karoon Energy +3.8% Core Lithium +3.1% Champion Iron +2.9% At the other end, Bellevue Gold has dropped the most so far — it's down 2%. The other major falls have gone to: De Grey Mining -1.6% Evolution Mining +1.3% Cochlear -1.1% Capricorn Metals -1% And unsurprisingly, Westpac has had some positive movement — so far its share price is up 3% thanks to its mammoth $4 billion profit posted in its half-yearly results.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens higher, led by resources gains

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is speaking in Perth and has mentioned another cost of living relief measure coming in tomorrow night's budget. He's announced the extension of the financial safety net for single parent families, by raising the cut-off age for the youngest child of a single parent from 8 to 14 years. That change will see a fortnightly increase by $176.90 a fortnight, and will cost the budget some $1.9 billion over the next four years, to 2026-27. The change reverses a decision that was made by the Gillard government.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Budget to include $1.9 billion package to extend single parent payments

children.content: is speaking in Perth and has mentioned another cost of living relief measure coming in tomorrow night's budget.
He's announced the extension of the financial safety net for single parent families, by raising the cut-off age for the youngest child of a single parent from 8 to 14 years.
That change will see a fortnightly increase by $176.90 a fortnight, and will cost the budget some $1.9 billion over the next four years, to 2026-27.
The change reverses a decision that was made by the Gillard government.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Finance minister Katy Gallagher says the government has "been mindful" that their decisions in the budget won't drive up inflation. She's told News Breakfast the measures have been "very carefully calibrated" and "carefully targeted". "We've been really mindful of that [inflation] as we've been putting the decisions in," she said. "It's affordable because we've been making savings on the other side of the  budget. We're trying to do a few  things, cost of living relief,  investing in the future production side of the economy, but also  repairing the budget at the same  time to deal with the debt and  deficit that we inherited. "Budgets are always hundreds if not thousands of decisions working together to  produce the final outcome. People  will judge that on Tuesday night. "But we've been very mindful of those cost of living pressures Australians as we've been finalising it."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will the cost of living relief package be inflationary?

children.content: says the government has "been mindful" that their decisions in the budget won't drive up inflation.

"It's affordable because we've been making savings on the other side of the  budget. We're trying to do a few  things, cost of living relief,  investing in the future production side of the economy, but also  repairing the budget at the same  time to deal with the debt and  deficit that we inherited.
"Budgets are always hundreds if not thousands of decisions working together to  produce the final outcome. People  will judge that on Tuesday night.
"But we've been very mindful of those cost of living pressures Australians as we've been finalising it."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Let's unpack what's going to be one of the centrepieces of the federal government's budget tomorrow night. One of the key measures that makes up this $14.6 billion relief package over four years includes a $1.5 billion energy bill subsidy for more than 5 million households and 1 million small businesses. Those eligible (pensioners, small businesses, and those on income support) will receive up to $500 relief on their power bills, but the size of the assistance depends on where you live. You can hear more about the energy bill relief package in tomorrow night's budget here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's in the $14.6 billion cost of living package in the budget?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Westpac is the latest major bank to post its half-yearly results, recording a $4 billion net profit — up 22% compared to this time last year. The bank is also increasing dividends to 70 cents per share, an increase of 15%. Westpac says the increase to its net profit was boosted by improving margins, thanks to rising interest rates and growth in home and business loans.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Westpac records $4 billion net profit in half-year results

Westpac says the increase to its net profit was boosted by improving margins, thanks to rising interest rates and growth in home and business loans.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning and welcome to another week — it's Monday, May 8 and budget eve. If you're as excited as I am about the budget (you are on a markets and financial blog, after all) you'll have keenly spotted the federal government is out spruiking a near- $15 billion cost of living package to be unveiled in tomorrow night's budget. The $14.6 billion support package over four years is aimed to ease pressure on households and businesses, including $1.5 billion for electricity bill relief for 5.5 million households and 1 million small businesses. (I'll unpack what we know about the relief package shortly.) On the markets front, we can expect the local sharemarket to open higher with ASX futures up, and greater investor sentiment thanks to all three major benchmarks gaining. Investors are also waiting for Westpac's half yearly results, which have just dropped as I post this. Let's get into it, shall we?
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX set to open higher on federal budget eve

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Analysis from EY shows Australia's big four banks reported combined statutory earnings of $16.77 billion in their half-yearly results — a 10.8% increase compared to this time last year. But EY says the major banks are walking a "challenging tightrope" and will have to manage competing demands from investors, customers, regulators and government in "an increasingly uncertain and volatile backdrop". EY says cash rate rises are boosting revenues and net interest margins, while higher earnings have pushed up return on equity, although some signs of mortgage stress are emerging. "Australia's major banks are walking a tightrope as headwinds for the sector intensify. The resilience of the Australian economy continued to support credit growth and quality throughout the first half of the year," said EY Oceania Banking and Capital Markets Leader, Doug Nixon. "However, intense competition in response to retail credit growth compression, coupled with rising funding costs, amplified by the recent dislocation in financial markets, will likely erode the benefits the banks have gained from the higher interest rate environment. "So, while Australia's major banks remain strong and resilient, pressure on net interest margins, combined with the increasingly uncertain operating environment, means they face a complex high-wire balancing act when it comes to managing profitable growth, customer expectations, investment priorities and shareholder returns."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Big four banks earn combined $16.77 billion in half-yearly results

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The world's largest crypto-currency exchange, Binance, has resumed bitcoin withdrawals after it was stopped twice today due to a large volume of pending transactions. The company tweeted that it had temporarily closed withdrawals because there were too many transactions, and its team was working on a fix. It isn't the first time Binance has suspended transactions, either. Back in March, it stopped deposits and withdrawals because of what it described as "technical issues". The price of bitcoin is down to its lowest in nearly a week, at around $41,000. Withdrawals have since resumed.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Binance resumes bitcoin withdrawals after 'large volume' of transactions

children.content: The world's largest crypto-currency exchange, Binance, has resumed bitcoin withdrawals after it was stopped twice today due to a large volume of pending transactions.
The company tweeted that it had temporarily closed withdrawals because there were too many transactions, and its team was working on a fix.
It isn't the first time Binance has suspended transactions, either.
Back in March, it stopped deposits and withdrawals because of what it described as "technical issues".
The price of bitcoin is down to its lowest in nearly a week, at around $41,000.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX is continuing to gain throughout trade today, up 0.7% as of 1pm AEST to 7,266 points. The gains are largely thanks to boosts in the energy and materials sectors, while Westpac is continuing to pick up after its half-yearly results, up 2.3%. Here's how the top five movers are currently looking: Lynas Rare Earths +10.8% Core Lithium +7.3% Life360 +7.1% Iluka Resources +5.3% Pilbara Minerals +4.8% Meanwhile at the other end, the five worst performers are a mixed bag: Block -5.4% Syrah Resources -4.7% Macquarie Group -2.4% Polynovo -1.9% Bellevue Gold -1.8%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX moving higher at lunch as materials and energy stocks rally
